content.description: Really good problem. Start low on two opposing side pulls, make a long move right to a hole and/or hueco, then topout to the left using some decent pockets. Using the pocket between the starting holds can give you a secure double-pinch if the first move is giving you trouble
content.location:
West side of the Blocbuster, around the corner right of Robin Hood

44.9442808, -110.7186679

content.description: Mostly a one-move-wonder, start scrunched up real low on two good edges. Make a low-percent deadpoint to a good pocket and follow up to a flake, top out above and to the right. Flake is friable but doesn't seem ready to break. Wouldn't suggest this problem unless you're really bored
content.location:
Around back to the left of Hoodoo You Do

44.9449929, -110.7170508

content.description:
I don't think this has been climbed before, as I had to clear a couple dead trees from the base. It's an awesome problem, even if it wasn't at the Hoodoos.

Sit start using two small-hand sized pockets, then keep body tension and be careful on your feet as you move up through various-sized pockets, out left to top out using some good edges on the corner. Stay with it for a rock-over mantle without very good hands.

There coulduld probably be some cool variations to this as well
content.location:
North face of the Blocbuster, around the corner left of Square Punch

44.9443130, -110.7186129

content.description: Absolutely awesome climb, landing looks sketchy but is actually quite nice. Start crossed on two pockets bottom right of the boulder and make left for a side pull. from there go up through some crimps and a pocket.
content.location: Towards the back of the hoodoo field, straight shot from the middle point of the loop you park in. very recognizable.

content.description: A short slab with nice feet and pockets to dig into. From the anchors you have options of different routes all across the face. Also it is easy enough to solo if you dont mind the height.
content.protection: An anchor at the top of the rock, the hangers will repeatedly appear and depending on the rangers that year.
content.location: Park in the one way and follow the path at the apex of the road back until you find the obvious slab, it is only a lil up the trail.

content.description: Find some good holds on the face and move up using edges and pockets. Some of the more solid rock in the Hoodoos with a committing finish
content.location:
Obvious tall pillar-like boulder northeast from Da Party boulder

44.9449540, -110.7170629

content.description: Start sitting on a mono and follow the thin flake. Traverse left and top out.
content.protection: Pads, a buddy and a healthy appetite for fun.
content.location: Take the trail at the corner of the one way and ease right at the large boulder thing and follow it back until you see it.

content.description: Sit start on the left side of Da Party boulder as far down as you can grab the wide opposing side pulls. A few compression moves gets you to the top. Harder than it looks due to feet not being very good
The rock is a little chossy, but overall a good problem with good movement. start on two solid edges towards the right of the boulder and traverse out left and up through pockets and Gastons.
content.location: in the back right corner of the hoodoos, impossible to miss.

content.description: A solid slabby slab with tender feet and alot of leaning. The beginning and ending are the cruxes with the middle being the easiest
content.protection: One good bolt and one rusty bolt and a tree which is much more solid.
content.location: Climb up the obvious massive boulder at the apex of the corner
